keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy, France's first ex-president to go to jail, is serving a five-year sentence for conspiring to fund his 2007 campaign with money from Muammar Gaddafi.

Sarkozy was convicted not of personally receiving Libyan funds, but of criminal association with aides Brice Hortefeux and Claude Guéant who arranged secret campaign financing via intermediaries linked to Gaddafi's intelligence apparatus.
The case is tied to the 'Bygmalion affair', a major scandal involving illegal campaign financing in French politics.
Sarkozy is currently in solitary confinement at La Santé prison, where he is placed in an isolation wing with restricted contact and limited privileges.
Sarkozy has appealed the sentence and maintains his innocence, arguing that the case is politically motivated and that he is being punished for revenge rather than wrongdoing.

France's President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin have publicly expressed support for Sarkozy, emphasizing that the imprisonment is not a political endorsement but a recognition of legal proceedings.
Despite legal challenges, Sarkozy will remain in prison under conditions that include solitary confinement, limited exercise, and restricted communication.
The case has sparked public debate about political accountability, the use of judicial power against former leaders, and the legitimacy of political prosecutions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicolas Sarkozy, France's first former president to go to jail, begins a five-year prison sentence for conspiring to fund his 2007 presidential campaign with money from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi. Though not personally implicated in receiving funds, he was convicted of criminal association with aides Brice Hortefeux and Claude Guéant, who arranged secret financial links via intermediary Ziad Tiakeddine. The case, known as the Bygmalion affair, has sparked intense public and political debate. Sarkozy is currently held in solitary confinement at La Santé prison, where he faces restrictive conditions including limited contact, exercise, and privacy. Despite filing an appeal and maintaining his innocence, the judicial system has upheld the conviction due to the 'exceptional seriousness' of the facts. The incident has raised broader questions about political accountability, judicial fairness, and the treatment of former leaders in the criminal justice system.
title: Sarkozy enters jail over campaign financing - France's first ex-president behind bars
